body:
The default arrow key action when maneuvering the pum is sub-optimal (\<left\> is \<up\> and \<right\> is \<down\>.  I see that @bfredl has attempt to fix this with the "\<down\> and \<up\> mappings for wildoptions=pum" commits, however this commit was reverted.

I thought that the below vimscript would be sufficient, but that causes command history to not complete based on a partially written command; e.g if my command history contains `write` and `edit`, and I type `:w` and press `<up>`, `:edit` is shown, not `:write`
```
if &wildoptions =~ "pum" 
    cnoremap <up> <c-p>
    cnoremap <down> <c-n>
endif
```
So, is it possible to only enable the mapping if the pum is active, or, preferably to fix the default behavior?

comment_data.body:
Changing the default behavior would make `wildoptions=pum` uncomfortable for users that are used to the old behavior but just want improved display. 

`wildmenumode()` would seem to fit the case here, but it returns false for some reason. 

**Edit:** as @bfredl noted, this works:

```
if &wildoptions =~# "pum"
  cnoremap <expr> <up> pumvisible() ? '<left>' : '<up>'
  cnoremap <expr> <down> pumvisible() ? '<right>' : '<down>'
endif
```

I don't think it's worth mentioning this in the help because it's very specific, and covered by standard practices.
Using `<expr>` mapping with `pumvisible()` should work, just as in insert mode.
The problem with the change of defaults (so that I had to revert it) is that `<down>` already has a meaning in wildmode: complete inside a subdirectory.
`f_wildmenumode` uses an internal value for `screen.c` drawing of wildmenu, it probably already failed for `ext_wildmenu`. When `State == CMDLINE` it should also return true for `pum_visible()`

I tried the following, but it still doesn't work well for command completion.
It would at least be nice with a workaround described in `:h wildoptions` as the default behavior is somewhat strange.

```
    if &wildoptions =~ "pum"
        cnoremap <expr> <down> pumvisible() ? "<C-n>" : "<up>"
        cnoremap <expr> <up>   pumvisible() ? "<C-p>" : "<down>"
    endif
```
You need to escape special keys in `<expr>` mapping strings, like `"\<c-n>"`

That did not make any difference. 
Also, the pum part of the mapping works (`"<c-n>"`), but `"<up>"` does not work as expected.
Is it intentional that they are reversed?

nope, typo
This actually works as expected:
```
    if &wildoptions == "pum"
        cnoremap <expr> <up>   pumvisible() ? "<C-p>" : "\<up>"
        cnoremap <expr> <down> pumvisible() ? "<C-n>" : "\<down>"
    endif
```

But how to also remap `<right>` to `<down>` so that `<right>` confirms the completion (when completing directories)?

```
cnoremap <expr> <left> pumvisible() ? "<up>" : "<left>"
cnoremap <expr> <right> pumvisible() ? "<down>" : "<right>"
```

The remapping of `<left>` works as expected, but not `<right>`.
Pressing `<right>` when completing files inserts `^I` into the commandline instead of confirming the completion.
@cjxgm it is a known issue. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/11001#issuecomment-536450197. It is on my TODO list for 0.5 (but otherwise it is a good entry level issue)

I would really like to solve this issue, but Im having trouble trying steps to build with `make`.

Here is the output after `make distclean` and `make`:

```
...
src='/home/user/neovim/.deps/build/downloads/msgpack/msgpack-3.0.0.tar.gz'
dst='/home/user/neovim/.deps/build/src/msgpack'
-- extracting... [tar xfz]
-- extracting... [analysis]
-- extracting... [rename]
-- extracting... [clean binary dir]
-- extracting... [clean up]
-- extracting... done
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.
make: *** [Makefile:101: deps] Error 1`
```

I tried the step in #2248 issue and some others, but it doesn't work.
My machine is: Debian 4.19.98-1 (2020-01-26) x86_64 GNU/Linux
Was this ever implemented? I can't find any information about it.
@ba-caf try `rm -rf .deps` and restart make. Feel free to ask on giter if you need help.
@Hezkore I believe it was implemented in #11746 (which is in 0.5 I think). Now it is possible to remap `<right>` as described above
What remains to be done about this issue?

This seems to work as expected:
```vim
cnoremap <expr> <Up> wildmenumode() ? '<Left>' : '<Up>'
cnoremap <expr> <Down> wildmenumode() ? '<Right>' : '<Down>'
cnoremap <expr> <Left> wildmenumode() ? '<Up>' : '<Left>'
cnoremap <expr> <Right> wildmenumode() ? '<Down>' : '<Right>'
```
contrary to what i said in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/9953#issuecomment-487384353 maybe a small doc update is needed here.

> In case someone need it, this is zeertzjq's solution in lua:
> 
> ```lua
> vim.api.nvim_set_keymap('c', '<Up>', 'wildmenumode() ? "<Left>" : "<Up>"', {expr = true, noremap=true})
> vim.api.nvim_set_keymap('c', '<Down>', 'wildmenumode() ? "<Right>" : "<Down>"', {expr = true, noremap=true})
> vim.api.nvim_set_keymap('c', '<Left>', 'wildmenumode() ? "<Up>" : "<Left>"', {expr = true, noremap=true})
> vim.api.nvim_set_keymap('c', '<Right>', 'wildmenumode() ? "<Down>" : "<Right>"', {expr = true, noremap=true})
> ```
> 
> Alternative version using the astro/[NormalNvim](https://github.com/NormalNvim/NormalNvim) utils:
> 
> ```lua
> maps.c["<Up>"] = { function() 
>   return vim.fn.wildmenumode() == 1 and "<Left>" or "<Up>" 
>   end, noremap = true, expr = true,
> }
> maps.c["<Down>"] = { function() 
>   return vim.fn.wildmenumode() == 1 and "<Right>" or "<Down>" 
>   end, noremap = true, expr = true,
> }
> maps.c["<Left>"] = { function() 
>   return vim.fn.wildmenumode() == 1 and "<Up>" or "<Left>" 
>   end, noremap = true, expr = true,
> }
> maps.c["<Right>"] = { function() 
>   return vim.fn.wildmenumode() == 1 and "<Down>" or "<Right>" 
>   end, noremap = true, expr = true,
> }
> ```

Those commands won't work for me, I get `<80>ku` printed on the command line. Any ideas why?
You are using `vim.keymap.set()` instead of `vim.api.nvim_set_keymap()`, and didn't specify `replace_keycodes = false`.

> replace_keycodes

thanks, that was it!

title: wildmenumode() with wildoptions=pum
